awd_titl_txt: Activation of Carbon-Hydrogen Bonds at Multinuclear Metal Sites
awd_abstract_narration:
Simple hydrocarbons such as methane and ethane are now available from abundant supplies of natural gas. However, since these materials cannot easily be converted into other products, they are not good feedstocks for the chemical industry. In large part, this difficulty arises because the carbon-hydrogen (C-H) bonds in hydrocarbons are relatively unreactive. In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Richard D. Adams, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of South Carolina, is developing methods to activate hydrocarbon C-H bonds. Metal complexes having two or more metal atoms are designed so that several C-H bonds in a hydrocarbon interact with the metals. These interactions activate the bonds and allow the hydrocarbons to be converted into valuable products, such as alcohols, aldehydes and carboxylic acids. These lead to new processes for the production of industrial materials. In addition to the scientific component, the project involves both graduate and undergraduate students, including ones from underrepresented groups and prepares them for careers in science and technology.

Multinuclear complexes of precious metal elements, such as ruthenium, rhodium, rhenium, iridium, and platinum, are evaluated for their ability to activate hydrocarbon C-H bonds. By using metal complexes having two or more metal atoms, multiple CH activations are achieved and several functionalities are introduced on a single hydrocarbon. The studies target C-C and C-O bond forming processes and include mechanistic investigations to uncover details of the transformations. New bimetallic complexes are converted into bimetallic nanoparticles to create a new generation of high activity heterogeneous catalysts. Broader impacts include the development of new processes for the conversion of simple hydrocarbons and related resources into valuable chemicals for use as industrial feedstocks. Graduate and undergraduate students are trained in the latest methods of scientific inquiry and analysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
In the course this project, we have completed and published 17 scientific reports in the chemical literature. The publications are individually cited with the final project report that will accompany the submission of this Outcomes report. In this report a summary of the work with emphasis on highlights of the project achievements will be provided.

The work in this project began with the discovery of multiple aromatic CH activations (bond cleavage) reactions by dinuclear rhenium carbonyl complexes involving mono- and polycyclic arenes and monocyclic heteronuclear arenes.

1)      The first examples of multi-CH activation in aromatic and heteroaromatic compounds by the oxidative addition of two or more dirhenium carbonyl complexes to a single aromatic ring or to fused polycyclic aromatic systems were discovered. In one case, we able to add four dirhenium carbonyl fragments to one anthracene molecule to form the complex [Re2(CO)8(μ-H)]4(μ−η2-1,2-μ−η2-3,4-μ−η2-5,6-μ−η2-7,8-C14H6) by the activation of four CH bonds (two CH bonds on each of the two external rings) of the C14 three-ring anthracene molecule. 

2)      In a few cases, aromatic heterocyclic compounds including furans and thiafurans were found to engage in multiple CH activations in reactions with selected dirhenium compounds. It was also discovered that that rings of these compounds could be opened by cleavage of one of the carbon-heteroatom bonds.

3)      We have discovered new examples of the activation of the formyl, HC=O, CH bonds of formamides and aldehydes by pentaruthenium carbonyl complexes. The acyl group of the ligands that were formed was found bridge an open edge in the pentaruthenium carbonyl cluster products in a dihapto-µ-C=O fashion. These new reactions will pave the way for the derivatization of aldehydes and olefins by subsequent carbon – carbon bond coupling reactions.

In more recent studies we have discovered that tertiary amines, such as trimethylamine, can be added to certain alkynes including acetylene, C2H­2 and selected mono-substituted alkynes in the presence of active metal complexes to create dipolar, zwitterionic ammonioalkenyl ligands, of the form -HC=C(H)+NR3, R = Me or Et in di- and polynuclear metal carbonyl complexes. The ligands can be coordinated in a terminal fashion by the terminal alkenyl carbon atom or in a sigma + pi bridging fashion to across two metal atoms in certain polynuclear metal complexes by using both of the carbon atoms of the alkenyl group. Formally, the metal complexes having these ligands contain both a positive charge on the nitrogen atom and a negative charge on the metal atom and they are called Zwitterions. The addition of the amine group to the alkyne group is reversible by cleavage of the carbon – nitrogen bond to the alkenyl group. The elimination of the amino group from the ammonioalkenyl ligand then generates a coordinated alkyne ligand. Studies have shown that some of the ammonioalkenyl ligands engage in facile C – C bond forming processes in coupling to other alkynes. 

 


Last Modified: 08/16/2023
Modified by: Richard D Adams
